sect1.title: Platform Overview
sect1.para: To be able to use &productname; on &rpi;, an &arm64; compatible &rpi; is required. &productname; is tested to work on a &rpi; 3 Model B board.

sect2.title: Technical Details of the &rpi; 3 Model B
sect2.para: The &rpi; is a series of small single-board computers based on a System on a Chip (SoC) by Broadcom*, featuring various peripherals on the board.

variablelist.title: Selected Features of the &rpi; 3 Model B

listitem.para: The Broadcom SoC includes a quad-core ARM* Cortex*-A53 cores supporting the ARMv8 32-bit and 64-bit instruction sets. With the default configuration, it is clocked up to 1.2 GHz.
1024 MiB DDR2 memory mounted on the back of the board.
Broadcom* VideoCore* IV providing OpenGL ES 2.0 support. Displays can be connected over HDMI or composite (TRRS jack).
A USB Ethernet adapter on the board provides 10/100MBit/s Ethernet.
The BCM43438 chip supports IEEE-802.11g, IEEE-802.11b and IEEE-802.11n in the 2,4 GHz band. It also provides Bluetooth 2.0-4.1 (Low Energy).
MicroSDHC card slot
The &rpi;'s main power source is the Micro USB connector. It is recommended to use the bundled power supply only.
A total of four USB 2.0 ports is available.
A 0.1 inch multi-function pin header is also available. Note that not all functionality of this header is exposed in &prodrpi;.

sect2.title: &productname; &productnumber;
sect2.para: &productname; &productnumber; is the first enterprise-class Linux operating system available free-of-charge for the &rpi;. During its lifetime, customers running a registered &prodrpi; system, will receive all released bug and security fixes, as well as feature updates.

note.title: No commercial support available
note.para: &suse; will not provide commercial support offers via &suse; Technical Support for &prodrpi;.

sect3.title: Differences Compared to Raspbian
sect3.para: Raspbian is the de-facto default distribution for the &rpi;. The following paragraphs provide a short overview of differences between &prodrpi; and Raspbian.

listitem.para: While Raspbian uses a kernel with modifications especially for the &rpi;, &prodrpi; uses the default &sle; kernel for &aarch64;.
&prodrpi; is the first distribution for the &rpi; using the &aarch64; instruction set.

In Raspbian, the kernel is loaded directly. This is not supported by &prodrpi;, where the U-Boot boot loader is used to provide an EFI boot environment. A GRUB2 EFI binary is chainloaded to provide a graphical boot screen.
&prodrpi; uses Btrfs as file system for the root partition. compression is enabled by default for better SD-Card performance.

sect3.title: &yast;
sect3.para: &yast; is the installation and configuration framework for &sle;. It is popular for its easy use, flexible graphical interfaces and the capability to customize your system quickly during and after the installation. &yast; can be used to configure your entire system: you can configure hardware, set up networking, manage system services and tune your security settings. All these tasks can be reached from the &yast; Control Center. To start it, choose &yast; in the menu or run the command xdg-su -c yast2. You will be prompted to enter the password of the &rootuser; user.
When started, &yast; shows an overview of available modules (). Simply click an icon to open a module.

sect1.title: Installation
sect1.para: &productname; for &rpi; is distributed as XZ-compressed image file for MicroSD cards. This section will guide you through the process of preparing the card to the first boot. If you already have a MicroSD card containing the image, you can skip this section and go straight to .

note.title: SD Card Space Requirements
note.para: It is recommended to use a card with a capacity of at least 8 GB.

warning.title: All Data on the Card will be Lost!
warning.para: By following the procedure below, all data on the SD card will be overwritten and therefore irrevocably lost! Be very careful when choosing the destination device of the image writing process!

sect2.title: Preparing the Card on Linux
sect2.para: Before and after you plug in the SD card, run the lsblk command. Between the two runs of lsblk, there should be a difference of one or more lines. The first column and first row is the name of the node representing the SD card in your system. To write the image to the card, use the dd command:

example.title: Writing the Image to the Card using dd
example.para: This command decompresses the image SLES-12-SP2-ARM-JeOS-raspberrypi3_aarch64-Build2.62.raw.xz to the SD card mmcblk0.

sect2.title: Preparing the Card on Windows*
sect2.para: The following steps will guide you through the installation of the image onto the SD card on Windows. You need to meet these prerequisites:

listitem.para: Latest available Image of &prodrpi;
Easy 7-Zip from http://www.e7z.org/
Win32 Disk Imager from http://sourceforge.net/projects/win32diskimager/

step.para: Open the downloaded image using Easy-7-Zip. Extract the file content into a folder with sufficient free space.
Run Win32 Disk Imager and select the extracted file as Image File. Then, choose the correct drive letter as Device. Click on Write to start the procedure.

note.title: Finding the correct device
note.para: If you are unsure which drive letter to choose from in the list, just remove the SD card and run Win32 Disk Imager again. The option that disappeared is the right target device.

sect2.title: Preparing the Card on macOS*
sect2.para: The following steps will guide you through the installation of the image onto the SD card on macOS. You need to meet these prerequisites:

listitem.para: Latest available Image of &prodrpi;
The Unarchiver from http://unarchiver.c3.cx/unarchiver

step.para: Open Finder at the location where the downloaded image is stored. Use the Open With selection to choose The Unarchiver instead of the default Archive utility and extract the content into a folder with sufficient free space.

textobject.phrase: Open the Image with The Unarchiver

step.para: Open a Terminal window and change into the destination directory of the uncompressed image. Enter diskutil list before and after the SD card is inserted to find out which device to use.
Run diskutil unmountDisk /dev/diskX, where X is the disk number from the previous step.
Run sudo dd bs=4096 if=imageFile.raw of=/dev/diskX, where X is the disk number and imageFile.raw is the name of the uncompressed image.
step.screen: &prompt.user;sudo dd bs=4096 if=SLES-12-SP2-ARM-JeOS-raspberrypi3_aarch64-Build2.62.raw of=/dev/disk4 Password: 5550+0 records in 5550+0 records out 5819596800 bytes transferred in 1131.796649 secs (5141910 bytes/sec)

step.para: Now unmount the disk (which is now labelled EFI) as usual.

sect1.title: Booting for the First Time
sect1.para: After insertion of the prepared MicroSD card, connect a display, Ethernet and USB keyboard and mouse first, then provide power over Micro USB. After a few seconds you should be able to see a few lines of text on the screen. If that is not the case, recheck the connection to the display.

note.title: Operation Without Mouse
note.para: &yast; can be used without a mouse by only using the keyboard. Every GUI element has an accelerator configured, visible as underlined letter. To activate such an accelerator, press the letter together with .

sect1.para: On the first boot, the system will expand to fill the entire SD card, so be patient.

sect2.title: Initial System Setup with &yast;
sect2.para: After a few minutes, &yast; will lead you through the initial system setup.

step.para: First, the system language and keyboard layout needs to be configured. Use the drop-down boxes and click Next.

textobject.phrase: &yast; showing keyboard and language configuration on first boot

step.para: Select Next on this screen.
Read the License Agreement. You need to accept the license by selecting I Agree to the License Terms and choosing Next.
Select the time zone either by clicking the area in the map or selecting region and zone in the drop-down boxes.
If the time and date shown at the bottom on the screen are incorrect, setup the &ntp; client by following these steps:
Click Other Settings to open the NTPD configuration.
Click Other Settings to synchronize date and time with NTPD.
After the synchronization completed, click Accept to return to the Time and Date overview.
Click Next to proceed.
On this page, you can configure a default user account.

note.title: Automatic Login not supported
note.para: Automatic Login is not supported by xdm, the default display manager. Install gdm after the installation to make it work.

step.para: If you chose to skip the previous step or not to set a root password, you will be asked to provide one now. Do not forget what you enter here, you will need it for administration!

textobject.phrase: &yast; asking you to set a password for the &rootuser; user

step.para: On this screen you need to enter your E-mail address and the registration code you received. You can also choose to Skip Registration.

note.title: Skipping the Registration
note.para: If you choose to skip the registration here, you will not receive updates or patches until you registered manually using &yast;

step.para: Click Finish to exit the setup wizard and continue the system startup.

textobject.phrase: &yast; congratulating you for finishing the initial configuration

sect1.title: General System Usage
sect1.para: After the initial configuration procedure and the first boot of the system, you can now use various components of the system.

sect2.title: Bluetooth*
sect2.para: The &rpi; has a Bluetooth* controller on-board that can be used for various purposes, like wireless keyboards, mice or audio devices.
To enable the Bluetooth* controller for use with bluetoothctl and related applications, run:
sect2.screen: &prompt.root;hciattach /dev/ttyAMA0 bcm43xx 921600 bcm43xx_init Flash firmware /lib/firmware/BCM43430A1.hcd Set Controller UART speed to 921600 bit/s Device setup complete
sect2.para: You can then use hciconfig hci0 up to bring the device up and use hcitool scan to scan the environment for discoverable devices.

sect2.title: Compiler
sect2.para: It is strongly advised to use the version 6 of the GNU Compiler Collection for compiling software. It is already installed as part of the Software Development Kit. To use it, gcc-6 has to be invoked instead of gcc.
